sections.heading: 14.1 Introduction
sections.text:
Conservation of cultural heritage is a subject under which the most varied chemical-physical techniques and different branches of science can be included, from engineering to biology, with one purpose: preserve and protect cultural artifacts in order to ensure their enjoyment. In this context, cultural heritage represents a very complex and challenging field, taking into account the great variability of materials included in this category and the different states of degradation, depending on the history of conservation every material has been subjected to.
Considering the complexity of the system, it has undoubtedly been demonstrated that a conservative project cannot be a successful one if it is not based on the collaboration between the conservation scientists and the restorer (Baglioni et al., 2015a,b). No one artwork can be preserved in the correct way if the materials are not characterized and their chemical behavior, with respect to the environment and considering the synergic actions among them, is not thoroughly assessed. Thus the proper scientific investigations have the

same importance as the restoration itself. This issue is also related to the need to answer different questions of art historians, such as geographical provenance, possible dating, and authenticity (Baglioni et al., 2015a,b). Scientific investigations are also necessary in testing the materials employed in the restoration process and evaluating the effectiveness and/or invasiveness of the treatment, drawbacks, presence of any residues, and so on (Bianchin et al., 2009; Baglioni et al., 2015a).
All these complex considerations, summarized in few lines, have divided this chapter in two sections. One section is dedicated to exploring the potentiality of different techniques connected with the concept of “nano”: they employ nanostructures for analytes detection (e.g., surface-enhanced Raman spectroscopy, SERS) or allow analysis on nanoscales or nanosamples (e.g., atomic force microscopy (AFM), voltammetry of nanoparticles). The aim is to evidence the advantage of their applicability to the characterization of artworks. The second part is focused, instead, on showing the application of nanomaterials in cleaning and conservation treatment on cultural heritage materials. A complete and exhaustive discussion of these topics could not even be contained in a single book. Instead, the purpose of the discussion of the next case studies is to provide an example of the potential of nanotechnology and nanomaterials and, at the same time, highlight the critical points that a conservator should face during his or her research. Every case, in fact, has specific features and issues, and no one technique or material can be applied automatically, but proper considerations should be made (Baglioni et al., 2015a).

sections.heading: 14.1.1 Nanotechnologies for Diagnostics: Case Studies
sections.text: The case studies reported in this section are considered indicative of certain applications or technologies that use nano systems or technologies that reach the nano as a field of inquiry. In particular, it will be reported case study of SERS analyses, nowadays recognized as a powerful instruments for the identification of organic dyes, and not only, in real small scale samples. Furthermore, attention will be focused on microscopic techniques, which allow characterizing materials on the nanoscales, providing both morphological and chemical information. Finally, some case studies are reported regarding the use of micro- and nanoparticles voltammetry, an electrochemical method, which allows analyzing samples on the nanograms scale.

sections.heading: 14.1.2 Surface-Enhanced Raman Spectroscopy Applications and Case Studies
sections.text:
SERS represents one of the most common nanotechnologies applied in the cultural heritage field. Since its discovery in 1974 (Fleischmann et al., 1974) and the model rationalization in 1977 (Jeanmaire et al., 1977), this technique has been applied in several diagnostic fields, but its use for detection of organic compounds in artworks and historical objects represents one of its principal applications (Leona et al., 2014).
326 Chapter 14
The surface enhancement that caused the outspread of the technique consists in a double effect of Raman spectral enhancement and fluorescence quenching (Pozzi and Leona, 2016a), which corresponds to fast registration of a high-quality spectrum, when the classic Raman spectrum on the same sample would be affected by high fluorescence interference or it would take more time to be recorded.
The SERS effect is generated by the surface interaction of the analyte with noble metal (Au or Ag, principally) nanostructures; the accepted mechanism is based on the combination of electromagnetic (Jeanmaire et al., 1977) and charge-transfer ones (Albrecht and Creighton, 1977), even if the debate is still going ahead. However, independently from the responsible mechanism, it is a fact that SERS advantages have made possible the analysis of organic dyes in art-object samples, previously difficult with classic Raman spectroscopy for the high fluorescence background. Besides, the improvements in reproducibility allowed applying this technique massively to characterization and diagnostic of the main chromophores in real samples, which was previously limited to UV-Vis spectroscopy and chromatographic techniques. It is worth mentioning that, because of differences in resonances, affinity to nanocluster, concentration, and solubility of different chromophores eventually present in a dye mixture, it is not always possible to distinguish among the several components, but nevertheless this technique represents an extremely sensitive tool for this class of analytes (Pozzi et al., 2016b).
Thus SERS analysis on cultural heritage objects started with the analysis of textile dyes (Guineau and Guichard, 1987), which is still one of the main applications. The first approaches on real samples involved the extraction of dye from the solid sample with strong acids and bases. The strong acid/base extraction usually obtains a quantitative extraction yield; also, because of its “hard” characteristics, it can be applied when less common dyes are used or no other information is available. For instance, Leona applied the HCl extraction for the analysis of berberine from a 18th century Tibetan textile that included inserts from other periods; for example, a 17th century one (Leona and Lombardi, 2007). The sample had already been analyzed with high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) and the presence of berberine was assessed; nonetheless, this real sample constituted a good real test for the application of SERS. The SERS spectrum of HCl extract perfectly matched the berberine standard one, and the analysis was carried out on a very small sample fiber (1 mm length, about 50 mm diameter), a quantity 50 less than the HPLC corresponding one. Of course, the detection of a less common dye involved density functional theory (DFT) experiments, comparison of SERS spectra with theoretical and experimental Raman spectra, and assumptions of the molecule behavior at the Ag nanoparticles interface, but the analysis was successful on an ancient and degraded object with fast measurements (100 scans in comparison to normal Raman, 2000 scans).
Nanotechnologies and Nanomaterials 327
Different extraction procedures can be necessary according to the different type of sample. Bruni et al. (2011a) used an extraction with N, N-dimethylformamide at 70 C to extract a purple dye on a bone fragment found in the tomb of the martyrs Gervase and Protase in the Basilica of Sant’Ambrogio, Milano (4th century AD), while an extraction with MeOH/ HCl was used for a red dye on a wool thread from the Royal Tumulus of In Aghelachem (300 BCeAD 350) in the Libyan Sahara. SERS analysis provided the spectrum of 6,60-dibromoindigotin, characteristic of Tyrian purple, in the bone sample, while madder dye was found as lake on the wool one. In addition, in the same work a variation of relative intensities of SERS peaks was suggested as a possible marker to differentiate Tyrian purple from other indigoids produced by other shellfish.
From this point of view, another interesting study was conducted with a milder extraction procedure on two archaeological threads from the Lybian Sahara, in a region that was under Garamantian control (Bruni et al., 2011b). In this case, after the comparison with SERS spectra obtained on fluoridric acid (HF) extracts of pomegranate and sumacdtwo tannin-rich plantsdthe yellow dye present on these samples was identified as a pomegranate-derived colorant. Several remarks are needed: in this study chromatographic analyses were first used with SERS, and they were useful to exclude other yellow dyes (e.g., flavonoid dyes as weld), but they were not considered decisive to discriminate between pomegranate and sumac dyes, as opposed to SERS. Furthermore, in this case SERS has put into evidence some degradation phenomena of discovered analytes. Finally, the use of this technique has provided archaeobotanical information on the dyeing technology in the Garamantian sites.
Nonetheless, because of the degradation products interference and sample disruption, new, gentler methodologies have been applied. Leona et al. (2006) has applied a gas-solid extraction, treating a sample from a 16th century Netherlandish tapestry with vapors of HF in a solid chamber: this nonextractive hydrolysis has been successful for the identification of alizarin on the sample.
The individuation of specific protocols was fundamental, even for the identification of specific dyes. Platania et al. (2015) used a combination of leuco reagents, NaOH and Na2S2O4 (1:2, w:w), to obtain an inverse dyeing process for the detection of indigo in textiles of different typologies: a pre-Colombian textile, a 15th century tablecloth, and a 16th century Medici tapestry. In all the cases, the use of SERS resulted in high-quality spectra, whereas the classic Raman ones were affected by strong fluorescence or did not show indigo bands for the low signal-to-noise ratio. Even if indigo is usually detectable by normal Raman spectroscopy, its identification can be hard for aged and degraded samples; in this case, SERS overcame every problem.
The work of Platania is also important for the use of an extraction solid matrix (Lofrumento et al., 2013; Platania et al., 2014). This sampling procedure consists of an
328 Chapter 14
Agar gel cube where Ag nanoparticles are dispersed. The microcube is put in contact with the sample after wetting with an adequate solvent and, after the proper extraction time (about 30 min), SERS analysis is performed on the extract dried on the cube surface. Before of the indigoids case, this methodology was combined with ethanol extraction to detect red dyes from a pre-Colombian textile: in this case, a good spectrum of alizarine was recorded, which is the main component of madder dyes. The gel methodologies present a lot of advantages in comparison with the standard SERS. In particular, the metal nanoparticle interaction is favored because of their drying shrinkage, while the combination with several extractions solvents allows extraction of several dyes.
A development in SERS application results from the analysis directly on the fiber. An example is constituted by the analysis of a 19th century Easter canvas painting (Gui et al., 2013). SERS was performed on some fiber samples and it identified not only organic dye (indigo), but also inorganic pigments, cellulose, and lignin components of the canvas without any pretreatment. In particular, for the fiber components, SERS analysis was more powerful than classic Raman, because according to this study it can discriminate lignincontaining fibers from those that do not, with fast spectra acquisition (10e25 s integration time).
Another recent application of in situ SERS was presented by Serafini et al. (2017). In this case, SERS analysis was performed directly on the fiber of two samples from a 1865 dress of a Sicilian noblewoman to obtain preliminary information on the classes of the dyes used. This preliminary analysis individuated mauveine and a mixture of mauveine/orchil dyes directly on the two samples; this was fundamental to select specific and different protocols (Lombardi et al., 2016) for the dye extraction from the two samples separately and the following ultra-HPLCemass spectrometry analysis.
However, it is fundamental to underline that SERS use is not limited to textiles; it is now an important tool for the identification of organic dyes in other artistic objects. The application to paintings is now a matter of fact. Pozzi et al. (2014) used SERS in order to characterize the red lake pigments used by French impressionist and post-impressionist painters (Fig. 14.1). In this case, the HF extraction was used because no SERS signal could be registered by simple colloid deposition on the samples, probably because the analyzed glazes were rich in different paint materials. The analysis was performed on 13 paintings by Manet, Pissarro, Monet, Renoir, and Gauguin, and it showed different lakes were used by French painters in the 19th century, from madder-based lakes to cochineal to Kopp’s purpurin. Furthermore, through SERS it was possible to identify a mixture of different lakes in Renoir’s Woman at the Piano, to individuate madder lake in samples that did not show the characteristic orange fluorescence and to discriminate a retouching material from the original one in a painting layer of about 20 mm. Finally, SERS

characterized as cochineal lake the red lake used for a totally faded area in Renoir’s Madame Léon Clapisson.
The HF vapor extraction was used by Leona (2009) not only for textiles but for surfaceenhanced resonance Raman spectroscopy, the corresponding resonance variant of SERS (SERRS) analysis of painting glazes. The procedure was applied to samples of Egyptian painted leather of the Middle Kingdom, where it predated the use of madder in Egypt by seven centuries before according previous information. In the same study, lac dye was identified through SERRS in a 12th century wooden sculpture of the Virgin and Child (Morgan Madonna). The identification of the same glaze dye in another sculpture of the same period and provenance allowed information about the trade and manufacture of lac dye to be obtained.
330 Chapter 14
Another extraction strategy was used by Idone et al. (2014). In their work, they focused the attention on cross sections, mounting some samples derived from a 13th century wooden statue of the Virgin with the Child and from a mural painting that contained both 16th and 20th centuries color layers. In this case, SERS analysis was performed using a silver colloidal paste: this is the result of sequential centrifugation of silver colloid in order to concentrate nanoparticles (Fig. 14.2). Then, the colloidal paste was dropped on the cross sections for analysis. Attention was focused on the best concentration optimization, 10 mg of colloidal paste diluted with 2 mL of ultrahigh quality water. Recorded SER spectra identified a madder-type dyestuff for the statue and kermes lake pigment for the 16th century layer in the mural painting. Furthermore, from the relative intensity of alizarine and purpurine peaks, the dye source plant was identified as different from common madder (Rubia tinctorum L.).
Colloidal paste was also used by Frano et al. (2014) to identify carmine lake in historical oil paintings. In particular, attention was focused on the possibility of surface mapping through SERS on samples with a defined layer structure. In Daher’s et al. (2014) work, SERS analysis was performed by dropping a simple colloid on the samples derived from a painted weaving shuttle and a commode, where carmine and madder lakes were identified, respectively. The nonhydrolysis approach was also used by Clementi to characterize some pink particles found in the Domus Aurea paintings. In this case, dropping the silver colloid directly on the sample particles identified a madder lake (Clementi et al., 2011).
An interesting approach for SERS sampling is used by Cesaratto et al. (2014) for the characterization of painted areas in some art objects. In this case, SERS was combined with UV laser ablation, which can vaporize small areas (about 20 mm diameter) in painting samples and cross sections. The sample is exposed to HF vapor and the ablated and analyzed with SERS (Fig. 14.3). This approach was successful for the identification of lake pigments in painted areas of different types. Madder lake was found on a 16th century painted dish, while kermesic acid lakes were found both on a sample from a Luca Signorelli’s fresco and on Giorgione’s Adoration of the Shepherds. UV laser ablation in combination with SERS provided better results than simple SERS, probably because of the absence of other layers’ interference and consequential higher spatial resolution.
Although the main application of SERS is in the natural dyes identification field, this technique is also used for the identification of other artistic materials. For instance, Lau et al. (2008) used SERS in order to characterize the risen component in the varnish used for a Tiepolo painting. Natural resins present strong fluorescence in the Raman spectrum, as most organic binders. In this work, the combination of silver nanoparticles with copper foils according to an adapted procedure by Nie and Feng (2002) resulted in an SERSactive surface characterized by size-optimized nanoparticles. This strategy was successful to record SER spectra of natural resins solutions and to identify dammar in the varnish of

Giambattista Tiepolo’s Banque of Cleopatra. The analysis was contemporary to restoration and it was applied on the extract of a cleaning cotton swab, a practical advantage that makes SERS very attractive.
An interesting study is the one published by Roldàn et al. (2014), who focused their attention to the identification of sepia pigments. Sepia is a pigment derived from eumelanin, which is very difficult to characterize and identify because of its insolubility and oligomeric characteristics. In this study, different spectroscopic techniques were applied to characterize several types of sepia, and SERS revealed both signal enhancement and new spectral characteristics compared to normal Raman spectrum. Raman and SERS
were used to characterize the ink used by Robert Frederik Blum’s Waiting for Aaron, and in particular SERS was essential to identify unambiguously sepia presence.
SERS is also used to characterize modern and contemporary materials. Cesaratto et al. (2017) applied the technique to the identification of acid red dyes based on the naphthol red. After a laboratory study on reference material, SERS was applied to identify these colorants on Japanese woodblock prints dating to the 1890s. In this case, standard SERS approach (pretreatment with HNO3 and HF and colloid placement) was not successful, while a second approach, consisting of soaking analytes on moist filter paper from the back of the print, obtained SERS spectra. Nonetheless, for some acid dyes standard Raman was found to provide spectra with a higher signal-to-noise ratio. This suggests that when no information is available about the nature of the unknown analyte a simple Raman trial has to be preferred and, in the case of high fluorescence, it has to be followed by SERS.
Nevertheless, the technique presents remarkable advantages and it is now a wellexperienced method, proven by the large number of case studies available in literature. Further developments include a wider database of spectra of less common dyes, the realization of new less invasive sampling methods, and the extension of the method to the identification of other compounds.

sections.heading: 14.1.3 Atomic Force Microscopy and High-Resolution Scanning Electron Microscopy
sections.text:
High-resolution microscopy techniques can provide information about surfaces with depth and lateral resolution in the order of nanometer or less. It is clear that similar characteristics are extremely captivating in the cultural heritage field: art objects could be subjected to degradation phenomena with different distribution on the surface, and their spatial characterization can be very useful to understand conservation history of the artworks. This is a very interesting feature if we think that cleaning and conservation treatments can implicate morphological changes on materials, and it is fundamental to identify these processes on the nanoscale to optimize formulations and avoid aesthetic variations. Finally, the high resolution microscopic knowledge of systems can provide useful information in discriminating materials or identifying their provenance.
Because of multiple advantages, high-resolution microscopy techniques such as AFM, transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and field-emission gunescanning electron microscopy (SEM) are used for very different applications in diagnostics and conservation, from metal patina analysis to ancient glass degradation study to restoration materials characterization.
An example of these technique potentialities is provided by the study of Garcı́a-Heras et al. (2005) on historical glass decay, which was conducted totally with AFM. The art object was a historical glass from a stained window of the 13th century Cathedral of Leon, which
334 Chapter 14
showed diffuse corrosion phenomena. In this case, AFM analysis was performed in noncontact mode; the tip approaches very close to the surface (10 nm) but there is no direct contact. Optical microscopy and SEM imaging evidenced an overall alteration layer with random craters and pits full of insoluble salt crystals; through AFM the alteration layer height was characterized between 180 and 380 nm, while high crystallinity was individuated for the salt deposit, with height between 300 and 400 nm. While all these roughness characteristics were observed for the outdoor exposed surface, on the internal one a grain height between 200 and 400 nm was observed, while the glassy matrix in less altered areas had a grain height between 5 and 40 nm. In order to explain the possible processes involved in the degradation of the window, AFM was applied to glass samples artificially aged. The comparison of AFM analysis on mock-ups correlated the formation of pits and insoluble salt deposit to alkaline attack to glass network, while atmosphere pollutants in combination with humidity implicated the formation of the overall degradation layer.
Following this example, Carmona et al. (2010) applied the same technique to several glass samples of different provenances and periods (13th to 17th centuries) to individuate eventual degradation phenomena. The analysis of modernist glasses, where some microcracks and pits were detected, evidenced a good conservation state. Average roughness was around 10 nm, but first degradation could be diagnosed in comparison with a new analogous glass, which showed a roughness of 2 nm. On the contrary, a more ancient glass from the Baroque period evidenced better preservation conditions; the roughness was only about 3 nm. This was correlated both to a conservation environment with low concentrations of pollutants and to the high content of PbO, which decreases the surface roughness of glassdthe analogous recent glass had a roughness of 0.3 nm. A Renaissance glass, instead, presented a surface roughness of 30 nm, in contrast with the laboratory glass analogue of 3 nm. In this case, AFM was applied as a monitoring tool, a great advantage especially because the technique can be applied directly in situ with portable instruments (Fig. 14.4).
In the same research field, Schalm and Anaf (2016)applied the field emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM)- energy-dispersive X-ray spectrometry (EDX) to characterize the degradation process, which transforms a clear glass in an opaque material. In particular, they focused on the formation of lamellae on a glass surface through analysis of glass objects between the 14th and 17th centuries. For example, one sample from an excavation in Antwerp and dated from the 16th to 17th centuries presented two types of lamellae: the first one was 3e4 mm large, the second one was about 1 mm. Backscattering analysis suggested a difference in density among the lamellae, while SEM imaging of a microscopic fragment evidenced the presence of further smaller lamellae. In particular, these different lamellae showed interstitial spheres with size between 171 and 244 nm. Actually, the authors observed a different transformation on the same sample and hypothesized that the degradation process consists of formation of silica nanoparticles packed in a random way, which makes the material a colloidal glass.
